Award.AwardTitle: Catalyzing New International Collaboration: US-Singapore collaborative initial data gathering activities on mechanics of quantum and semi-classical conductors
Award.AbstractNarration:
This US-Singapore project will catalyze a new international collaboration between the PI's experimental group at SUNY-Buffalo and a theoretical group at the Nanyang Technological University in Singapore. During the PI's team visit to Singapore, the PI's recent experimental results on mechanical stability of atomic-sized conductors as small as a single-atom bridge will be analyzed theoretically, focusing on the size dependence of the modulus enhancement and deformation modes at the Fermi length scale. This will lay the foundation for the longer term objective of understanding the role of crystal structure and atomic coordination, temperature, and surface energy, on the stability of atomic-sized samples.
Involvement of students in this activity will help to develop their capacities to be comfortable with both experimental and theoretical approaches. The project will help establish a theoretical and quantitative
framework to explain the mechanics of quantum and semi-classical conductors.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The UG students involved in this project had the opportunity to work in PI’s lab over the summer of 2015 (with several students later continuing to work in PI’s lab after that). During this time, these students have had the opportunity to work on a transformative new development in the field of magnetism called non-Joulian magnets, which was discovered by PI in 2015. The students worked on various aspects of these energy efficient magnets, ranging from magnetization measurements, magnetostriction measurements, circuit development for new experimental design, and sample preparation for micromagnetics. These are some of the key methods that are used to characterize magnets, and this field has large footprint in industry from data storage to spintronics.

In 2015, the focus of PI’s research shifted drastically by the transformative and groundbreaking discovery of a new phenomenon in magnetism called Non-Joulian Magnetostriction. This was published in Nature (H. D. Chopra and M. Wuttig, Nature vol. 521, p. 340-343 (2015), followed by filing of a patent. PI then followed it up by publishing another related paper recently in Nature in 2016; Addendum: Non-Joulian Magnetostriction, H. D. Chopra and M. Wuttig, Nature vol. 538, p. 416 (2016).

Prior to the discovery of non-Joulian magnets, all magnets were thought to follow the 170-year-old principle called Joulian magnetostriction whereby magnets change their shape but conserve their volume when placed in a magnetic field. Non-Joulian magnetostriction upended this 170-year-old principle and showed that these newly discovered magnets increased their volume in a magnetic field.

As a result of this discovery PI became focused on non-Joulian magnets and goals of this Collaborative grant to study nanoscale contacts were not continued. Nor did the PI had the means at that time (instrument wise) to pursue them. The students who were recruited also ended up working in the new field of non-Joulian magnetostriction. So the funds in this Collaborative grant were not spent and are being returned back to NSF.
